prompt_templates.title: Basic ECS Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me a basic Unity ECS setup with component definitions, an ISystem implementation, and how to use SystemAPI.Query to iterate over entities.

output_examples.input: Create a health system that damages enemies when they collide with projectiles
output: Define Health and Damage components with IComponentData
Use IAspect to group transform, health, and collider data
Create DamageSystem with EntityQuery filtering for enemies and projectiles
Implement IJobEntity with collision detection logic
Add BurstCompile attribute for maximum performance

best_practices: Always use ISystem instead of SystemBase for better Burst compatibility and performance
Apply BurstCompile to all jobs and systems to achieve maximum CPU optimization
Use EntityCommandBuffer to batch structural changes rather than modifying entities directly in jobs
anti_patterns: Avoid using managed types in components as they break Burst compilation
Do not perform structural changes (create, destroy, add, remove) inside parallel jobs
Avoid iterating entities one-by-one; use parallel jobs and chunk iteration instead

faq.question: What Unity version supports ECS and DOTS?
faq.answer: Unity 2022.3 LTS and newer versions have stable DOTS support. Earlier versions had preview packages.

faq.question: How many entities can Unity ECS handle?
faq.answer: ECS can handle hundreds of thousands of entities with proper architecture. Performance scales linearly with proper job usage.

faq.question: Can I mix GameObjects and ECS entities?
faq.answer: Yes, use baking to convert GameObjects to entities. Hybrid approaches are common during migration.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only provides documentation. It does not access, read, or modify any files on your system.

faq.question: Why is my Burst-compiled code running slowly?
faq.answer: Ensure all types are unmanaged, no garbage collection occurs, and you are using ScheduleParallel for iteration.

faq.question: How does ECS differ from traditional OOP game architecture?
faq.answer: ECS stores data contiguously by component type rather than per-object, enabling cache-friendly memory access patterns.
